snippet.textDisplay: People might not agree with me, but I feel like Sakuraba lost his unique touch. When I compare his early Tales and Star Ocean soundtracks to what he's doing now, it's like he's just on automatic drive now pumping out tons of uninspired music. Maybe it's not that surprising with the amount of Tales games that came out. This theme is a perfect example of Sakuraba magic.
snippet.textOriginal: People might not agree with me, but I feel like Sakuraba lost his unique touch. When I compare his early Tales and Star Ocean soundtracks to what he's doing now, it's like he's just on automatic drive now pumping out tons of uninspired music. Maybe it's not that surprising with the amount of Tales games that came out. This theme is a perfect example of Sakuraba magic.

snippet.textDisplay: I mainly think Sakuraba phones in the OSTs that he does for new Tales of games. The music he composes for other game series is generally better (if not exactly amazing).
snippet.textOriginal: I mainly think Sakuraba phones in the OSTs that he does for new Tales of games. The music he composes for other game series is generally better (if not exactly amazing).

snippet.textDisplay: Go Shiina is the best thing to happen to the Tales series musically by far.
snippet.textOriginal: Go Shiina is the best thing to happen to the Tales series musically by far.

snippet.textDisplay: Completely agree. Besides Tales of Phantasia, Tales of Destiny, Star Ocean 2 (and to a lesser extent the original Star Ocean), I had a really hard time getting into any of his other work. There were some good tracks here and there, but most were filler imo, with a lot of monotonous droning.
snippet.textOriginal: Completely agree. Besides Tales of Phantasia, Tales of Destiny, Star Ocean 2 (and to a lesser extent the original Star Ocean), I had a really hard time getting into any of his other work. There were some good tracks here and there, but most were filler imo, with a lot of monotonous droning.

snippet.textDisplay: Indeed I don't agree with you, Sakuraba created a lot of memorable compositions after this game, it's not fair to diminish them.
snippet.textOriginal: Indeed I don't agree with you, Sakuraba created a lot of memorable compositions after this game, it's not fair to diminish them.

snippet.textDisplay:
Probably to a lesser degree, but, Sakuraba has always had this issue. Tales of Eternia's OST sounds like it was made entirely of unreleased Star Ocean 2 tracks.
Some of the Baten Kaitos tracks he composed however sounded like he was let off his leash which was obviously well after ToE.
snippet.textOriginal:
Probably to a lesser degree, but, Sakuraba has always had this issue. Tales of Eternia's OST sounds like it was made entirely of unreleased Star Ocean 2 tracks.
Some of the Baten Kaitos tracks he composed however sounded like he was let off his leash which was obviously well after ToE.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a HUGE fan of Sakuraba's early works, and I totally agree. The last game he helped compose for (period, not just Tales) that grabbed me was Vesperia. Even then, he'd been past his prime for a while.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a HUGE fan of Sakuraba's early works, and I totally agree. The last game he helped compose for (period, not just Tales) that grabbed me was Vesperia. Even then, he'd been past his prime for a while.

snippet.textDisplay:
I remember from an interview that Sakuraba did some years ago where he mentioned that he would have liked to do something different for the tales games but he was asked not to make the sound too thick or something to that effect and tries to stay within a specific tales theme. Tales of Graces and onward is when I personally started to notice uninspiring tracks.

I am almost certain that had it not been for this we would've seen more of his magic. And that outside of Tales we get to see him work relatively unfettered like in Dark Souls, for example.
snippet.textOriginal:
I remember from an interview that Sakuraba did some years ago where he mentioned that he would have liked to do something different for the tales games but he was asked not to make the sound too thick or something to that effect and tries to stay within a specific tales theme. Tales of Graces and onward is when I personally started to notice uninspiring tracks.

I am almost certain that had it not been for this we would've seen more of his magic. And that outside of Tales we get to see him work relatively unfettered like in Dark Souls, for example.

snippet.textDisplay: Hmm, he never really stood out for me except for his battle themes, and even considering that I can barely remember the last few pieces from him.
snippet.textOriginal: Hmm, he never really stood out for me except for his battle themes, and even considering that I can barely remember the last few pieces from him.

snippet.textDisplay: I haven’t really liked anything he’s written since Golden Sun. He’s just phoning it in now.
snippet.textOriginal: I haven’t really liked anything he’s written since Golden Sun. He’s just phoning it in now.

snippet.textDisplay: No i fully agree, its actually why i kind of wish he'd just step away from the franchise for a while, i think its a massive missed opportunity for the games to feel distinct by not allowing them to have different composers like say a FF game.
snippet.textOriginal: No i fully agree, its actually why i kind of wish he'd just step away from the franchise for a while, i think its a massive missed opportunity for the games to feel distinct by not allowing them to have different composers like say a FF game.

snippet.textOriginal: @terracannon876 his music certianly fits and are catchy, but are hardly memorable.

snippet.textDisplay: I've actually never been a huge fan of Sakuraba music...  They work great in the game, but they almost never capture my attention as standalone music pieces.  This one is better than most that I've heard, and perhaps this has to do with me starting with the later games?
snippet.textOriginal: I've actually never been a huge fan of Sakuraba music...  They work great in the game, but they almost never capture my attention as standalone music pieces.  This one is better than most that I've heard, and perhaps this has to do with me starting with the later games?

snippet.textDisplay: Haven't played the most recent Tales games yet, but I did notice a dip in quality for the OSTs as the series went on..
snippet.textOriginal: Haven't played the most recent Tales games yet, but I did notice a dip in quality for the OSTs as the series went on..

snippet.textDisplay: As a huge Tales fan I can sorta get where you are coming at.  I do still feel he hits it dead on with some songs but as much as I love Graces f for it's fun battle mechanics, I can't remember much of the music.
snippet.textOriginal: As a huge Tales fan I can sorta get where you are coming at.  I do still feel he hits it dead on with some songs but as much as I love Graces f for it's fun battle mechanics, I can't remember much of the music.

snippet.textDisplay: This game is so underrated. Going back and replaying on it SNES is always a treat when you come at it from a perspective of how revolutionary it was at its time. It's nearly a PSX experience on a SNES cartridge.
snippet.textOriginal: This game is so underrated. Going back and replaying on it SNES is always a treat when you come at it from a perspective of how revolutionary it was at its time. It's nearly a PSX experience on a SNES cartridge.

snippet.textDisplay: What version did you play?
snippet.textOriginal: What version did you play?

snippet.textDisplay: @genesisSOC Ah. Yea, guess the chibi graphics never bothered me. I did enjoy the extra dialogue cutscenes and the extra optional character. The original was still an amazing game though.
snippet.textOriginal: @genesisSOC Ah. Yea, guess the chibi graphics never bothered me. I did enjoy the extra dialogue cutscenes and the extra optional character. The original was still an amazing game though.

snippet.textDisplay: @onresonance I have, but I'm not a fan of the more chibi graphics and weak combo system. It also makes the game much easier. It's certainly not bad by any means, but I really prefer the SNES version.
snippet.textOriginal: @onresonance I have, but I'm not a fan of the more chibi graphics and weak combo system. It also makes the game much easier. It's certainly not bad by any means, but I really prefer the SNES version.

snippet.textDisplay: Have you played the PSX remake? It improves on the original in almost every way.
snippet.textOriginal: Have you played the PSX remake? It improves on the original in almost every way.
